item.title: NATO Wants Germany to Provide 40,000 Additional Troops
item.description: The North Atlantic Treaty Organization wants Germany to contribute as many as 40,000 more troops for the alliance’s defense against Russia, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Michael Nienaber

media:content.media:description: German soldiers take part in a drill during the NATO Quadriga military exercise, in Pabrade, Lithuania, on Wednesday, May 29, 2024. Quadriga 2024 will be the largest German land forces exercise since Russia's full scale invasion of Ukraine in 2022.

item.title: UK’s Nissan Backing Shows Starmer’s Push to Save Industrial Jobs
item.description: The prospect of new support from the UK government for Nissan Motor Co. is the latest sign of Prime Minister Keir Starmer’s push to protect Britain’s industrial base as he tries to stave off a political threat from Nigel Farage’s Reform party and preserve the Japanese automaker’s famous Sunderland plant.
item.dc:creator: Joe Mayes, Jamie Nimmo

media:content.media:description: The Nissan production plant in Sunderland, England.

item.title: Chile Government Unveils Bill That Would Fully Legalize Abortion
item.description: Chile’s government on Wednesday presented legislation that would allow women to interrupt early-term pregnancies, an attempt to fulfill a pledge by leftist President Gabriel Boric before he leaves office early next year.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Malinowski

media:content.media:description: The La Moneda Palace in Santiago, Chile, on Sunday, Jan. 5, 2025. Chile's central bank will publish the minutes to its December policy decision, when board members cut borrowing costs by a quarter-point to 5% and signaled a pause to easing ahead.

item.title: Mexico’s Judicial Reform Is Now In the Hands of Confused Voters
item.description: Lea la nota en español
item.dc:creator: Maya Averbuch, Alex Vasquez

media:content.media:description: Advertisement promoting the judicial elections in Iztapalapa, Mexico City, Monday, May 12, 2025. Fred Ramos for Bloomberg

item.title: Israel Says It Killed Mohammed Sinwar, Head of Hamas in Gaza
item.description: Israel said it killed the top commander of Hamas in Gaza, confirming reports from earlier this month.
item.dc:creator: Fares Alghoul, Dan Williams

media:content.media:description: A bus destroyed by an Israeli airstrike outside the Gaza European Hospital in Khan Younis, on May 14. Photographer: Ahmad Salem/Bloomberg

item.title: Slovak Auto Industry Warns of Higher Taxes, Shift Away from EU
item.description: Slovakia’s auto industry warned that Prime Minister Robert Fico’s government risks hurting a dominant sector in the country with tax increases and a geopolitical shift away from key trade partners.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Hornak

media:content.media:description: Sparks fly as robotic arms weld panels of automobiles on the production line at an auto plant in Zilina, Slovakia.

item.title: ASML Urges Consistency on Taxes After Dutch Government U-Turn
item.description: ASML Holding NV called on the Dutch government to ensure stable investment and fiscal policy, criticizing tax policy decisions that reduced benefits for foreign workers.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Van Oosterom, Charlotte Hughes-Morgan

media:content.media:description: Construction work at the ASML Holding NV headquarters in Veldhoven, Netherlands.

item.title: Polish Far-Right Leader Fails to Endorse Any Presidential Rival
item.description: Poland’s far-right leader Slawomir Mentzen said he would not endorse any of the two remaining presidential candidates ahead of a tightly-contested election slated for Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Maciej Martewicz

media:content.media:description: Slawomir Mentzen

item.title: Israel-backed Group Says Gaza Aid Being Delivered, Denies Deaths
item.description: The foundation backed by Israel and the US to hand out aid in Gaza said it’s operating for a second day, and denied reports of deaths and casualties when Palestinians overran a distribution site on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Ethan Bronner

media:content.media:description: Displaced Palestinians wait to receive a free meal from a charity food distribution center in Gaza City, northern Gaza, on Tuesday, May 27, 2025. Germany is considering restrictions on military exports to Israel over concerns about civilian suffering in Gaza, a notable shift from one of the country's biggest weapons suppliers.

item.title: Germany to Help Kyiv Build Long-Range Missiles to Strike Russia
item.description: Germany agreed to provide Ukraine with €5 billion ($5.7 billion) in military aid as part of Chancellor Friedrich Merz’s pledge to help Kyiv build long-range weapons to hit targets on Russian territory.
item.dc:creator: Michael Nienaber, Olesia Safronova

media:content.media:description: Volodymyr Zelenskiy and Friedrich Merz in Berlin on May 28. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

item.title: Harvard, MIT Lead Elite Colleges’ $4 Billion Debt Spree After Trump Threat
item.description: Elite American universities have taken on more than $4 billion in additional debt since March that will help protect their finances as the Trump administration takes aim at their budgets.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Albright, Elizabeth Rembert

media:content.media:description: A student in front of the Harry Elkins Widener Memorial Library on the Harvard University campus in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

item.title: Nationalist Candidate Backs Crypto in Tight Polish Presidential Race
item.description: Poland’s nationalist candidate Karol Nawrocki has pledged to support the cryptocurrency industry if he wins a tightly-contested presidential election on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: Konrad Krasuski

media:content.media:description: Karol Nawrocki, candidate for President of Poland, speaks from the stage to his supporters at the end of March for Poland at Castle Square in Warsaw, Poland, on Sunday, May 25, 2025. The slump in Polish stocks, one of the year’s global equity standouts, signals that traders are increasingly jittery about any more political surprises.

item.title: EU Trade Chief to Speak to US Secretary Lutnick, Greer on Thursday
item.description: The European Union’s trade chief, Maros Sefcovic, said he plans to speak to US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick and US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer on Thursday, as the EU has sought to fast-track negotiations to reach a deal ahead of a July 9 deadline.
item.dc:creator: Max Ramsay

media:content.media:description: Maros Sefcovic

item.title: Fannie, Freddie to Keep US Guarantee If Taken Public, Trump Says
item.description: President Donald Trump said that the US government would retain guarantees and an oversight role over Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac even as he pursues a public offering for the mortgage giants.
item.dc:creator: Derek Wallbank

media:content.media:description: WASHINGTON, DC - MAY 04: U.S. President Donald Trump speaks to reporters on the south lawn of the White House on May 04, 2025 in Washington, DC. The President spent the weekend in Florida and returned to Washington on Sunday. (Photo by Tasos Katopodis/Getty Images)

item.title: Malaysian Ministers Quit in Blow to Anwar’s Government
item.description: Malaysia’s Economy Minister Rafizi Ramli and Natural Resources and Environmental Sustainability Minister Nik Nazmi Nik Ahmad are leaving the cabinet, days after they were defeated in an internal party election that was marred by allegations of vote-rigging and nepotism.
item.dc:creator: Anisah Shukry

media:content.media:description: Rafizi Ramli Photographer: Samsul Said/Bloomberg

item.title: Merz’s Government Set to Drop Fast-Track Path to Citizenship
item.description: Chancellor Friedrich Merz’s cabinet moved to abolish a measure that allowed well-integrated migrants to qualify for citizenship after three years in the country, according to government officials.
item.dc:creator: Michael Nienaber

media:content.media:description: Photo by Matthias Balk/picture alliance via Getty Images) Photographer: picture alliance/dpa/picture alliance

item.title: Thai, Cambodian Leaders Agree to Resolve Border Row After Clash
item.description: Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra and her Cambodian counterpart Hun Manet agreed to resolve a border row “as quickly as possible” after gunfire exchanges between rival troops early on Wednesday left a Cambodian soldier dead.
item.dc:creator: Suttinee Yuvejwattana, Pathom Sangwongwanich

media:content.media:description: Thai soldiers.

item.title: Milei Intervenes in Currency Market Despite Letting Argentine Peso Float
item.description: After pledging a free-floating currency a month ago, Argentina’s government has intervened in the market to influence the peso’s value, a move that stands in sharp contrast to its commitments to the International Monetary Fund.
item.dc:creator: Ignacio Olivera Doll

media:content.media:description: The Central Bank of Argentina in Buenos Aires. Photographer: Erica Canepa/Bloomberg

item.title: Falling Russian Oil Prices Drive Exports’ Value to Two-Year Low
item.description: Moscow’s crude export prices slipped for a seventh straight week
item.dc:creator: Julian Lee

media:content.media:description: Russia shipped 3.39 million barrels a day in the four weeks to May 25, with exports worth the least in more than two years.

item.title: Australia Looks to Avoid a Panama Repeat in China Port Showdown
item.description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is confronting a fresh diplomatic dilemma with China: How to fulfill a pledge to regain control of a strategic port without jeopardizing improved relations with his country’s largest trading partner.
item.dc:creator: Ben Westcott, James Mayger

media:content.media:description: The Port of Darwin in Australia.

item.title: China’s Policy Rebalancing Toward Consumption, Keyu Jin Says
item.description: China can boost production of high-end technological goods without undermining its push to lift domestic consumption, economist Keyu Jin said.
item.dc:creator: Josh Xiao

media:content.media:description: Economist Keyu Jin Photographer: Lluis Gene/Getty Images

item.title: Zelenskiy Says Kyiv Needs $30 Billion to Boost Arms Output
item.description: Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskiy called on western allies to provide about $30 billion by the end of the year to boost domestic weapons production and hold off Russia’s advance.
item.dc:creator: Daryna Krasnolutska, Volodymyr Verbianyi

media:content.media:description: UNSPECIFIED, UKRAINE - FEBRUARY 21: Ukrainian soldiers of the 108th Territorial Defense Brigade test fly a Ukrainian-made Vampire drone, with six rotors, night vision and thermal imaging capabilities, and capable of carrying four 82mm artillery shells, near the southern frontline on February 21, 2024 in UNSPECIFIED, Zaporizhzhia Oblast, Ukraine. Russian forces have been mounting multiple attacks each day along the 600-mile frontline, while Ukrainian troops grapple with a shortage of ammunition and manpower. (Photo by Scott Peterson/Getty Images)

item.title: Boston Pushes Harvard, Other Colleges for Money Even as Trump Steps Up Attacks
item.description: Boston is pressuring Harvard University and other local colleges to funnel millions more into the city’s tax coffers, a push that’s becoming increasingly complicated as the Trump administration intensifies its attacks on higher education.
item.dc:creator: Greg Ryan

media:content.media:description: Michelle Wu

item.title: NATO Floats Cybersecurity to Be Included in New Spending Target
item.description: NATO proposed including expenditures on cybersecurity and activities related to border and coastal security to qualify for the military alliance’s new defense-related spending target of 1.5% of GDP.
item.dc:creator: Donato Paolo Mancini, Andrea Palasciano, Daniel Basteiro, Jasmina Kuzmanovic

media:content.media:description: Mark Rutte

item.title: Iran May Allow American IAEA Monitors Under New Nuclear Deal
item.description: Iran will consider allowing the International Atomic Energy Agency to send US inspectors to monitor the country’s atomic activity if a new nuclear deal is brokered with Washington.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla

media:content.media:description: The Bushehr nuclear power plant in Iran. Photographer: Morteza Nikoubazl/Getty Images

item.title: Zelenskiy Embarks on a Key Month for Ukraine
item.description: Welcome to Balance of Power, bringing you the latest in global politics. If you haven’t yet, sign up here.
item.dc:creator: Daryna Krasnolutska

media:content.media:description: Relatives and military personnel welcome Ukrainian servicemen following a major prisoner of war (POW) swap with Russia at an undisclosed location in Ukraine, on Friday, May 23, 2025. Ukraine’s capital was targeted by a Russian drone and missile barrage overnight, hours after the warring sides started a large prisoner swap that’s due to continue over the weekend. Photographer: Andrew Kravchenko/Bloomberg

item.title: EU Plans to Create a Maritime Security Hub in the Black Sea
item.description: The European Union wants to create a maritime security hub in the Black Sea to monitor potential threats and protect critical infrastructure, Kaja Kallas, the EU’s top diplomat, told reporters on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Andrea Palasciano

media:content.media:description: French Navy aircraft carrier Charles-de-Gaulle. Photographer: Clement Mahoudeau/Getty Images

item.title: Finland Starts Process to Withdraw From Landmine Ban Treaty
item.description: Finland started the process of withdrawing from the Ottawa Convention, which bans anti-personnel landmines.
item.dc:creator: Kati Pohjanpalo

media:content.media:description: Landmines in Ukraine.

item.title: BOJ’s Bond Holding Paper Losses Hit Record After Rate Hikes
item.description: The Bank of Japan amassed the largest amount of unrealized losses on record from its government bond holdings in the year ended March, highlighting the challenges it faces in unwinding more than a decade of extraordinary monetary easing.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka

media:content.media:description: the Bank of Japan headquarters in Tokyo.

item.title: Trump’s Nippon Steel Bid Support Boosts Japan’s Trade Talk Hopes
item.description: President Donald Trump’s pivot to champion Nippon Steel Corp.’s bid to buy US Steel Corp. raises the prospect of fresh positive momentum for Japan’s sluggish negotiations with the US over tariff relief.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Gale, Erica Yokoyama

media:content.media:description: The US Steel Corp. Edgar Thomson Works in Braddock, Pennsylvania, US. Photographer: Justin Merriman/Bloomberg
